title: Fear in the Night
descriptions:
Fear in the Night (1947) is a tense psychological noir about a man trapped between a nightmare and reality. Vince, a mild-mannered bank teller, awakens from a vivid dream in which he murders a stranger in a mirrored room, leaving behind unmistakable clues. He’s shaken to find a mysterious puncture mark on his wrist and physical traces that suggest the dream might have been real. Terrified he’s lost his mind—or committed an unremembered crime—Vince confides in his brother-in-law, Cliff, a skeptical yet dogged police officer.

Cliff begins to investigate, trying to determine whether Vince is delusional or being manipulated. The two follow fragments from Vince’s dream—an address, a distinctive mirror-filled nightclub, a woman’s perfume—until they locate an estate that eerily matches Vince’s vision. Inside, the labyrinth of mirrors and the sense of déjà vu deepen Vince’s dread, while Cliff’s suspicions shift from Vince to the possibility of a calculated frame-up.

As clues accumulate, a sinister hypnotist emerges at the center of the plot, having implanted suggestions in Vince’s mind to turn him into an unwitting weapon. The scheme involves jealousy, blackmail, and a planned murder made to look like the confused act of a man in a trance. Cornered by the evidence and the psychological trap, Vince must confront the hypnotist’s hold over him while Cliff races to gather proof before another killing—or a forced confession—seals Vince’s fate.

The final confrontation in the mirrored room fractures truth from illusion, exposing the mastermind and clearing Vince, while leaving a lingering chill about the fragility of memory and how easily fear can be manufactured in the dark hours of the night.
